stem: An 80-year-old client is brought in by his daughter for a 6-month history of 'acting strange.' Based on the documentation, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Progressive decline in gait and cognition.
Background: No history of stroke. Lives at home.
Assessment: Client has a wide-based gait and seems to 'glue' his feet to the floor. Daughter says he has started 'wetting the bed.'
Recommendation: Large-volume lumbar puncture trial.

tabs.title: Cognitive & Mobility Differential
tabs.content:
Condition TriadCurrent FindingInterpretation
Wobbly (Gait)Wide-based; 'Magnet gait'Frontal lobe compression
Wacky (Cognition)Mild memory loss; Slowed thinkingDementia mimic
Wet (Incontinence)Frequent urinary accidentsSphincter control loss
CT BrainVentricle enlargement out of proportion to atrophyHydrocephalus suspected

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 128/78, HR 72, RR 16, T 98.4°F. Client is alert and oriented to person and place.

actionOptions.text: Assess the client's gait and continence before and after a large-volume Lumbar Puncture (LP)

parameterOptions.text: Level of orientation and short-term memory

rationale.correct: The client presents with the classic triad of Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH): gait disturbance (wide-based, 'magnet gait'), cognitive impairment (mild memory loss, slowed thinking), and urinary incontinence. A large-volume lumbar puncture (LP) is often performed to assess if CSF drainage improves symptoms, which would indicate that a shunt may be beneficial. Assessing gait and continence before and after the LP (a1) helps determine the effectiveness of CSF drainage. Fall precautions (a2) are crucial due to the gait instability. Monitoring gait stability and urinary continence (p1) and cognitive function (p2) are essential to evaluate treatment effectiveness.
clinicalPearls: NPH is a potentially reversible cause of dementia.
The classic triad of NPH is 'Wet, Wacky, and Wobbly'.
A large-volume LP can help determine if a shunt is likely to be effective.

questionTrap.trap: Assuming cognitive decline in an elderly patient is always Alzheimer's disease.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Consider other potential causes of cognitive decline, especially when accompanied by gait disturbance and urinary incontinence. The 'Wet, Wacky, and Wobbly' triad is highly suggestive of NPH.

mnemonic.title: NPH Triad
mnemonic.expansion: Wet (urinary incontinence), Wacky (cognitive impairment), Wobbly (gait disturbance).
